fields.name: Uruk-hai
fields.height: Shorter than Men, taller than other Orcs
fields.about: Uruk-hai (for short, Uruks) were brutal warriors of Middle-earth, and the strongest breed of Orc.

fields.name: Gundabad Orcs
fields.about: In Middle Earth, the Gundabad Orcs were the inhabitants of Mount Gundabad situated at the northern end of the Misty Mountains. They invaded the mountain and conquered it from the grasp of Dwarves of Durin who were originally inhabiting there. Before that, the Gundabad Orcs served under the Witch-king of Angmar. After the fall of Angmar, Mount Gundabad became the stronghold of all the Orcs.

fields.name: Spiders
fields.origin: Those who spoke were vicious and malevolent creatures, and their presence considered a blight.
fields.about: Giant, sapient spiders, also known as the Children of Ungoliant,

fields.name: Orcs/Goblins
fields.origin: The first documented appearance of Orcs was in Y.T. 1330, when the Sindar observed in Beleriand.
fields.languages: Black Speech; numerous Orkish languages; Westron
fields.about: Orcs were a race of humanoid creatures best known for their service as footsoldiers and slaves to the Dark Lords of Middle-earth. Even when not in thrall to an evil master, Orcs rarely if ever had non-violent interactions with Elves, Men, or Dwarves. They were known by many names by the various peoples of Middle-earth.

fields.name: Nazgûl
fields.about: The Nazgûl (Black Speech: Ringwraiths, sometimes written Ring-wraiths), also known as the Nine Riders or Black Riders (or simply the Nine), were Sauron's "most terrible servants" in Middle-earth. They were mortal Men who had been turned into wraiths by their Nine Rings of power.

fields.name: Balrog
fields.origin: Balrogs, or Valaraukar were Maiar that were seduced and corrupted by Melkor into his service.
fields.about: Originally, in unrecorded ancient times, the Balrogs were fiery Maiar that were persuaded by Melkor's might and splendor to join his cause. Their first dwelling was in Utumno, the fortress of Thangorodrim, but after their master's defeat during the War for Sake of the Elves, the Balrogs and other creatures in Melkor's service escaped to Angband and hibernated there.

fields.name: Smaug
fields.origin: Details unknown although still considered young.
fields.about: Smaug was the greatest fire-breathing dragon of the Third Age. In T.A. 2770 he attacked the Lonely Mountain and the town of Dale.
